channel.title: golang on Math and Data
channel.description: Recent content in golang on Math and Data

item.title: Welcome to the Mad site!
item.description: The Mad (Math and Data) group was created in fall 2016 by Afonso Bandeira, Joan Bruna and Carlos Fernandez-Granda, three Assistant Professors at the Courant Institute and the Center for Data Science. We are always in the lookout for highly motivated students interested in understanding and developing the fundamental mathematical structures underpinning modern data analysis, machine learning, deep learning, and their applications.

item.title: the MIC Seminar
item.description: The Mathematics, Information and Computation (MIC) Seminar runs at irregular intervals and covers specific aspects at the interface of applied maths, information theory and theory of computation. Schedule Fall 2019 Date Speaker Title Room Aug 13, 12:30pm Zhizhen Jane Zhao (UIUC) Cryo-Electron Microscopy Image Analysis with Multi-Frequency Vector Diffusion Maps CDS 650 Aug 29, 12pm Jerry Li (MSR Redmond) Efficient Learning from Untrusted Batches CDS 650 Jerry Li: Efficient Learning from Untrusted Batches In recent years there has been an explosion of interest in designing unsupervised learning algorithms able to tolerate adversarial corruptions in the input data.

item.title: Reading Groups
item.description: The MaD group hosts semester-long thematic reading groups, which are publicly accessible here. Current (Fall 2019) We are running a general group meeting, on the broad theme of “statistical and computational tradeoffs in high-dimensional inference.” Information and our schedule are available here. Previous Spring 2019 We organized three working groups on different topics: The low-degree polynomials method; notes available here Nonconvex optimization Optimal transport Fall 2018 We ran a working group on the theme of “statistical-to-computational gaps and statistical estimation with algebraic structure.

item.title: Faculty
item.description:
Core Joan Bruna Assistant Professor, Department of Computer Science, Center for Data Science and Mathematics (affiliated).
Carlos Fernandez-Granda Assistant Professor, Department of Mathematics and Center for Data Science.
Julia Kempe Professor, Department of Mathematics, Computer Science and Center for Data Science.
Jonathan Niles-Weed Assistant Professor, Department of Mathematics and Center for Data Science.
Afiliated Gerard Ben Arous Professor, Mathematics, Courant Institute. Xi Chen Assistant Professor, IOMS, Stern School.

item.title: Postdocs and Fellows
item.description:
Yossi Arjevani (Sept 2019 - ) Postdoc, Center for Data Science; optimization, machine learning.
Léo Miolane (Sept 2019 - ) Postdoc, Department of Mathematics and Center for Data Science; probability, statistics.
Qing Qu (Sept 2018 - ) CDS Moore-Sloan Fellow; signal processing, machine learning, optimization.
Grant Rotskoff (Sept 2017 - ) Postdoc, Courant Institute; statistical mechanics, machine learning.
Matthew Trager (Sept 2018 - ) Postdoc, Center for Data Science; algebraic geometry, deep learning.

item.title: the MaD Seminar
item.description: The MaD seminar features leading specialists at the interface of Applied Mathematics, Statistics and Machine Learning. It is partly supported by the Moore-Sloan Data Science Environment at NYU. Room: Auditorium Hall 150, Center for Data Science, NYU, 60 5th ave. Time: 2:00pm-3:00pm, Reception will follow. Subscribe to the Seminar Mailing list here Schedule with Confirmed Speakers Date Speaker Title Sep 5 Facundo Memoli (OSU) Gromov-Wasserstein distances and distributional invariants of datasets Sep 19 Dustin Mixon (OSU) Sep 26 Madeline Udell (Cornell) Oct 3 Rahul Mazumder (MIT) Oct 10 Peyman Milanfar (Google Research) Oct 17 Oct 24 Po-Ling Loh (UW-Madison) Oct 31 Nov 7 David Blei (Columbia) Nov 14 Marco Cuturi (Google Brain) Nov 21 Elchanan Mossel (MIT) Dec 5 Lenaic Chizat (Orsay-Paris Sud) Schedule Spring 2019

item.title: the MaD Seminar Fall 2017
item.description: The MaD seminar features leading specialists at the interface of Applied Mathematics, Statistics and Machine Learning. Room: Auditorium Hall 150, Center for Data Science, NYU, 60 5th ave. Time: 2:00pm-3:00pm, Reception will follow. Subscribe to the Seminar Mailing list here Schedule with Confirmed Speakers Date Speaker Title Sep 14 Yoram Singer (Princeton) Adaptive Regularization Sep 21 Esteban Tabak (NYU) Conditional Density Estimation through Optimal Transport Sep 28 Laurent Demanet (MIT) Extrapolation from sparsity Oct 5 Dustin Mixon (Ohio State) A semidefinite relaxation of k-means clustering Oct 12 Lorenzo Rosasco (MIT) (un)conventional regularization for efficient large scale machine learning Oct 19 Francis Bach (INRIA, ENS) Bridging the Gap between Constant Step Size Stochastic Gradient Descent and Markov Chains Oct 26 Rachel Ward (UT Austin) Nov 2 Ivan Selesnick (NYU) Nov 9 Mauro Maggioni (John Hopkins) Multiscale Methods for Dictionary Learning, Regression, Measure Estimation and Optimal Transport for data near low-dimensional sets Nov 16 Emmanuel Abbe (Princeton) Graph Powering: mixing Bayesian and spectral methods Nov 23 THANKSGIVING Nov 30 Guillermo Sapiro (Duke) Learning to Succeed while Teaching to Fail: Privacy in Machine Learning Systems Dec 7 Alexandre d’Aspremont (ENS) Abstracts Yoram Singer: Adaptive Regularization We describe a framework for deriving and analyzing online optimization algorithms that incorporate adaptive, data dependent regularization, also termed preconditioning.

item.title: the MaD Seminar Fall 2018
item.description: The MaD seminar features leading specialists at the interface of Applied Mathematics, Statistics and Machine Learning. It is partly supported by the Moore-Sloan Data Science Environment at NYU. Room: Auditorium Hall 150, Center for Data Science, NYU, 60 5th ave. Time: 2:00pm-3:00pm, Reception will follow. Subscribe to the Seminar Mailing list here Schedule with Confirmed Speakers Date Speaker Title Sep 13 Nate Silver Forecasting the midterm elections Sep 20 Ivan Selesnick (NYU Tandon) Sparse Regularization via Convex Analysis Sep 27 Cristopher Moore (Santa Fe Institute) Statistical physics, statistical inference, and community detection in networks Oct 4 Andrew Blumberg (UT Austin) Topological data analysis for scientific inference Oct 11 Venkat Chandrasekaran (Caltech) Learning Regularizers from Data Oct 18 Cathy O’Neil Big data, inequality, and democracy: what can mathematics offer?

item.title: the MaD Seminar Spring 2017
item.description: The MaD seminar features leading specialists at the interface of Applied Mathematics, Statistics and Machine Learning. Room: Auditorium Hall 150, Center for Data Science, NYU, 60 5th ave. Time: 2:30pm-3:30pm, Reception will follow. Subscribe to the Seminar Mailing list here Schedule with Confirmed Speakers Date Speaker Title Jan 26 Dave Donoho (Stanford) Optimal Shrinkage of Covariance Matrices in light of the spiked covariance model Feb 2 Andrew Gelman (Columbia) Taking Bayesian Inference Seriously Feb 9 Mar 20 May 11 Leslie Greengard (Courant) Inverse problems in acoustic scattering and cryo-electron microscopy Feb 16 Ronald Coifman (Yale) Organization and Analysis on data tensors Feb 23 John Wright (Columbia) Nonconvex Recovery of Low-Complexity Models Mar 2 Gitta Kutyniok (TU Berlin) Optimal Approximation with Sparse Deep Neural Networks Mar 9 Philippe Rigollet (MIT) Learning determinantal point processes Mar 16 SPRING BREAK Mar 23 Amit Singer (Princeton) PCA from noisy linearly transformed measurements Mar 30 Stephane Mallat (ENS Ulm) Mathematial Mysteries of Deep Convolutional Networks Apr 6 11am, 12 Waverly pl, L120 Ben Recht (UC Berkeley) Optimization Challenges in Deep Learning Apr 13 Waheed Bajwa (Rutgers) Collaborative Dictionary Learning from Big, Distributed Data Apr 20 Andrea Montanari (Stanford) The Landscape of some Statistical Learning Problems Apr 27 Joel Tropp (Caltech) Sketchy Decisions: Low-rank matrix optimization with optimal storage May 4 Thomas Strohmer (UC Davis) Murder, Matrices, and Minima - Adventures in Blind Deconvolution May 11 4pm Leslie Greengard (Courant) Inverse problems in acoustic scattering and cryo-electron microscopy Abstracts Dave Donoho: Optimal Shrinkage of Covariance Matrices in light of the Spiked Covariance Model (joint work with Behrooz Ghorbani, Stanford)

item.title: the MaD Seminar Spring 2018
item.description: The MaD seminar features leading specialists at the interface of Applied Mathematics, Statistics and Machine Learning. It is partly supported by the Moore-Sloan Data Science Environment at NYU. Room: Auditorium Hall 150, Center for Data Science, NYU, 60 5th ave. Time: 2:00pm-3:00pm, Reception will follow. Subscribe to the Seminar Mailing list here Note special time and location of the first talk by Sebastien Bubeck Schedule with Confirmed Speakers Date Speaker Title Jan 30, 3:45pm-5:00pm, WWH 1302 Sebastien Bubeck (Microsoft Research) k-server and metrical task systems on trees Feb 8 David Rothschild (Microsoft Research) Public Opinion during the 2020 election Feb 15, 3-4pm, CDS 150 Rachel Ward (UT Austin) Autotuning the learning rate in stochastic gradient methods Feb 22 Zhou Fan (Stanford) Eigenvalues in multivariate random effects models Mar 1 Thomas Pock (TU Graz) Learning better models for computer vision Mar 8 Amir Ali Ahmadi (Princeton) Polynomial Optimization and Dynamical Systems Mar 15 SPRING BREAK Mar 22 Mahdi Soltanolkotabi (USC) Learning via Nonconvex Optimization: ReLUs, neural nets and submodular maximization Mar 29 Alejandro Ribeiro (UPenn) Convolutional Neural Networks Architectures for Signals Supported on Graphs Apr 5 Justin Romberg (Georgia Tech) Solving Nonlinear Equations using Convex Programming Apr 12 Wotao Yin (UCLA) Asynchronous Parallel Computing for Optimization Apr 19 Anirvan Sengupta (Rutgers) Manifold Representation by an Unsupervised Neural Net: Biology, Mathematics and Computation Apr 26 Ankur Moitra (MIT) Robustness Meets Algorithms May 3 Rene Vidal (John Hopkins) Global Optimality in Matrix Factorization and Deep Learning Schedule Fall 2017

item.title: the MaD Seminar, Spring 19
item.description: The MaD seminar features leading specialists at the interface of Applied Mathematics, Statistics and Machine Learning. It is partly supported by the Moore-Sloan Data Science Environment at NYU. Room: Auditorium Hall 150, Center for Data Science, NYU, 60 5th ave. Time: 2:00pm-3:00pm, Reception will follow. Subscribe to the Seminar Mailing list here Schedule with Confirmed Speakers Date Speaker Title Feb 21 Jeffrey Pennington (Google) Dynamical Isometry and a Mean Field Theory of Signal Propagation in Deep Neural Networks Feb 28 Ahmed El Alaoui (Stanford) Efficient Z_q synchronization on the square lattice Mar 7 Florent Krzakala (ENS) Passed & Spurious: Descent algorithms and local minima in a spiked matrix-tensor model Mar 14 Rina Foygel Barber (Chicago) Distribution free prediction: Is conditional inference possible?
